answers.answer: Parathesia is a symptom.  It is an abnormal feeling or sensation.  Some can be just irritating, some can be very painful and unpleasant (dysesthesia.)  It is just a feeling.  The key here is the cause.If the cause is MS, a disease of the central nervous system, the pain and feelings are the result of "short circuits" in the wiring of the brain or spinal cord.  Your fingers, toes, feet, hands, etc. are usually fine.  The main computer (the brain) is "seeing signals" that are not valid.Now, if you have diabetes and the vasculature of your foot is compromised and the peripheral nerves are damaged, you can get parathesias, as a result of the damage.  Parathesias that are the result of peripheral nerve insult are typically called peripheral neuropathy.It is possible to have CNS caused parathesias and peripheral neuropathy at the same time and if you have a reason to suspect this, you should discuss it with you neurologist.  Just because you have MS, doesn't mean that there can be something else going on at the same time.In MS, parathesias themselves are harmless.  I have them in my feet and lower legs, worse on the right.  Every night or more often, when we are out camping or something, I check the soles of my feet and lower legs.  Little scrapes, ingrown toenails, puppy scratches, etc. may not hurt like they should.  Be very careful trimming your toe nails.  You want to make sure that any area of your body that has altered sensation gets a visual once over.  There are all sorts of nasty infections that can get out of control in just s few days.Bob

question: I am seriously questioning the effects of parathesia? I get the tingling, shocks, and pin pricks. Some nights I get them really bad. For 2 nights in a row I had them so bad and then I noticed I couldn't willfully curl my toes. People say that it is harmless put I can't understand how they can be harmless and do no damage misfiring.Am I missing something?Aloha!
title: Parathesia and nerve damage
